testCases.testName: Liver Grade I - Minimal Subcapsular Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Minor - Subcapsular hematoma <10% or capsular tear <1 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Subcapsular hematoma <10% surface area
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management (NOM) - Observation with serial clinical and laboratory monitoring

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - subcapsular <10% surface area = Grade I criterion. Step 3: No laceration present. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = I (Minor).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade I: Subcapsular hematoma <10% surface area

testCases.testName: Liver Grade I - Small Capsular Tear

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Minor - Subcapsular hematoma <10% or capsular tear <1 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Capsular tear <1 cm depth

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: No hematoma present. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - capsular tear <1 cm depth = Grade I criterion. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = I (Minor).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade I: Capsular tear <1 cm parenchymal depth

testCases.testName: Liver Grade II - Moderate Subcapsular Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Moderate - Subcapsular 10-50% or laceration 1-3 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Subcapsular hematoma 10-50% surface area

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - subcapsular 10-50% surface area = Grade II criterion. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = II (Moderate).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade II: Subcapsular hematoma 10-50% surface area

testCases.testName: Liver Grade II - Moderate Laceration with Multiple Injury Advancement

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration; Multiple injuries (+1 grade)
expectedOutputs.Multiple Injury Adjustment: Base grade 2 advanced to Grade 3 due to multiple injuries

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - 1-3 cm depth = Grade II criterion. Step 4: Multiple injuries present - advance one grade (II to III). Step 5: Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Multiple injury rule: Advance one grade for multiple injuries up to Grade III

testCases.testName: Liver Grade III - Large Subcapsular Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Serious - Large hematoma or deep laceration or contained bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Subcapsular hematoma >50% surface area
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Angioembolization for contained bleeding (15-25% may require); repeat CT if clinical change

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - subcapsular >50% surface area = Grade III criterion. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = III (Serious).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade III: Subcapsular hematoma >50% surface area

testCases.testName: Liver Grade III - Deep Laceration with Contained Bleeding

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Serious - Large hematoma or deep laceration or contained bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: >3 cm parenchymal depth laceration; Active bleeding contained within liver parenchyma

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - >3 cm depth = Grade III. Step 4: Vascular injury - contained active bleeding = Grade III. Step 5: Highest grade is III. Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade III includes: Laceration >3 cm depth AND vascular injury with bleeding contained within liver parenchyma

testCases.testName: Liver Grade IV - Major Lobe Disruption

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Severe - Major lobe disruption or intraperitoneal bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Parenchymal disruption 25-75% of hepatic lobe
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Angioembolization for active bleeding (33-40% require intervention); operative management if unstable

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - 25-75% lobe disruption = Grade IV criterion. Step 4: No additional vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = IV (Severe).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade IV: Parenchymal disruption involving 25-75% of hepatic lobe

testCases.testName: Liver Grade IV - Active Intraperitoneal Bleeding

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration; Active bleeding extending beyond liver into peritoneum; Subcapsular hematoma 10-50% surface area

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: Hematoma 10-50% = Grade II. Step 3: Laceration 1-3 cm = Grade II. Step 4: Vascular injury - active bleeding extending into peritoneum = Grade IV. Step 5: Highest grade is IV. Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade IV vascular criterion: Active bleeding extending beyond liver parenchyma into peritoneum

testCases.testName: Liver Grade V - Massive Lobe Disruption

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Critical - Massive disruption or juxtahepatic venous injury
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Parenchymal disruption >75% of hepatic lobe; Ruptured subcapsular/parenchymal hematoma
expectedOutputs.Liver-Specific Note: High-grade liver injuries have significant risk of delayed bleeding, biliary complications, and hepatic necrosis. Consider damage control surgery for unstable patients.

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: Ruptured hematoma = Grade III. Step 3: Laceration >75% lobe disruption = Grade V criterion. Step 4: Final Grade = V (Critical).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Liver Injury Scale Table - Grade V: Parenchymal disruption involving >75% of hepatic lobe

testCases.testName: Liver Grade V - Juxtahepatic Venous Injury

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Critical - Massive disruption or juxtahepatic venous injury
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Juxtahepatic venous injury (retrohepatic IVC/central hepatic veins); >3 cm parenchymal depth laceration
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: High-risk injury requiring aggressive management; consider early operative intervention
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Operative management often required (43-57% require surgery); damage control surgery for unstable patients

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Liver). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Laceration >3 cm = Grade III. Step 4: Juxtahepatic venous injury (retrohepatic IVC/central hepatic veins) = Grade V criterion. Step 5: Final Grade = V (Critical).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V vascular criterion: Juxtahepatic venous injuries including retrohepatic vena cava or central major hepatic veins

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade I - Small Subcapsular Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Minor - Subcapsular hematoma <10% or capsular tear <1 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Subcapsular hematoma <10% surface area
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management (NOM) - Observation; NOM success rate >95%

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - subcapsular <10% surface area = Grade I criterion. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = I (Minor).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade I: Subcapsular hematoma <10% surface area

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade II - Moderate Laceration

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Moderate - Subcapsular 10-50% or laceration 1-3 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - 1-3 cm depth = Grade II criterion. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = II (Moderate).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade II: Parenchymal laceration 1-3 cm in depth

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade II with Multiple Injury Advancement to Grade III

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration; Subcapsular hematoma 10-50% surface area; Multiple injuries (+1 grade)
expectedOutputs.Multiple Injury Adjustment: Base grade 2 advanced to Grade 3 due to multiple injuries

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Hematoma 10-50% = Grade II. Step 3: Laceration 1-3 cm = Grade II. Step 4: Multiple injuries - advance one grade. Step 5: Final Grade = III (advanced from II).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Multiple injury rule: Advance one grade for multiple splenic injuries up to Grade III

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade III - Deep Laceration

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Serious - Large hematoma or deep laceration
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: >3 cm parenchymal depth laceration
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management with close monitoring; consider prophylactic angioembolization

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Evaluate laceration - >3 cm depth = Grade III criterion. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = III (Serious).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade III: Parenchymal laceration >3 cm in depth

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade III - Large Intraparenchymal Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Intraparenchymal hematoma >=5 cm

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - intraparenchymal >=5 cm = Grade III criterion. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade III: Intraparenchymal hematoma >=5 cm or expanding

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade IV - Pseudoaneurysm/AVF

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Severe - Vascular injury (PSA/AVF) or >25% devascularization
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Pseudoaneurysm or AV fistula; 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management possible with angioembolization for vascular injuries
expectedOutputs.Spleen-Specific Note: Post-splenectomy patients require immunizations and have lifelong increased infection risk. Splenic preservation should be attempted when feasible.

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Laceration 1-3 cm = Grade II. Step 4: Vascular injury - PSA/AVF = Grade IV criterion (2018 update). Step 5: Highest grade is IV. Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade IV: Vascular injury (pseudoaneurysm or arteriovenous fistula) - Key 2018 revision addition

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade IV - Segmental Devascularization >25%

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Segmental/hilar vessel injury with >25% devascularization; Active bleeding confined within splenic capsule; Subcapsular hematoma >50% surface area

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Hematoma >50% = Grade III. Step 3: Laceration with segmental vessel injury and >25% devascularization = Grade IV. Step 4: Contained vascular bleeding = Grade IV. Step 5: Highest grade is IV. Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade IV: Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels producing >25% devascularization

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade V - Shattered Spleen

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Critical - Shattered spleen or hilar avulsion or free bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Shattered spleen; Ruptured subcapsular/intraparenchymal hematoma
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: High-risk injury; operative management (splenectomy) often required for unstable patients

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Ruptured hematoma = Grade III. Step 3: Shattered spleen = Grade V criterion. Step 4: Final Grade = V (Critical).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Spleen Injury Scale Table - Grade V: Shattered spleen

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade V - Hilar Devascularization

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Critical - Shattered spleen or hilar avulsion or free bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization; >3 cm parenchymal depth laceration
expectedOutputs.Follow-up: If splenectomy: Vaccinations (pneumococcal, meningococcal, H. influenzae); lifelong infection awareness

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Laceration >3 cm = Grade III. Step 4: Hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization = Grade V criterion. Step 5: Final Grade = V (Critical).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V: Hilar vascular injury that devascularizes spleen

testCases.testName: Spleen Grade V - Free Intraperitoneal Bleeding

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Active bleeding extending beyond spleen into peritoneum; 1-3 cm parenchymal depth laceration; Subcapsular hematoma 10-50% surface area
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Splenectomy for hemodynamic instability or free intraperitoneal bleeding; consider partial splenectomy if feasible

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Spleen). Step 2: Hematoma 10-50% = Grade II. Step 3: Laceration 1-3 cm = Grade II. Step 4: Active bleeding into peritoneum = Grade V criterion. Step 5: Final Grade = V.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V vascular criterion: Any injury with active bleeding extending beyond spleen into peritoneum

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade I - Parenchymal Contusion

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Minor - Contusion or subcapsular hematoma <3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Parenchymal contusion
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management (NOM) - Observation with clinical and urinalysis monitoring

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - parenchymal contusion = Grade I criterion. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: No vascular injury. Step 5: No infarction. Step 6: Final Grade = I (Minor).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale Table - Grade I: Parenchymal contusion without laceration

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade I - Small Subcapsular Hematoma

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Minor - Contusion or subcapsular hematoma <3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Subcapsular hematoma <3.5 cm

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: Evaluate hematoma - subcapsular <3.5 cm = Grade I criterion (uses Hematoma Rim Distance). Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: Final Grade = I.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale - Grade I: Subcapsular hematoma with HRD <3.5 cm

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade II - Small Laceration

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Moderate - Small laceration <2.5 cm or limited perinephric hematoma
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Parenchymal laceration <2.5 cm, no collecting system involvement; Perinephric hematoma with HRD <3.5 cm

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: Perinephric hematoma HRD <3.5 cm = Grade II. Step 3: Laceration <2.5 cm = Grade II. Step 4: No collecting system involvement. Step 5: Final Grade = II (Moderate).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale - Grade II: Laceration <2.5 cm and/or perinephric hematoma with HRD <3.5 cm

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade III - Large Laceration with Contained Vascular Injury

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Serious - Larger laceration or contained vascular injury or partial infarction
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Pseudoaneurysm, AV fistula, or contained active bleeding; Parenchymal laceration >=2.5 cm; Hematoma rim distance >=3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: Non-operative management with close monitoring; angioembolization for vascular injuries

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: HRD >=3.5 cm = Grade III. Step 3: Laceration >=2.5 cm = Grade III. Step 4: PSA/AVF or contained bleeding = Grade III (2018 criterion). Step 5: Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade III: Laceration >=2.5 cm, HRD >=3.5 cm, or contained vascular injury (PSA, AVF, contained bleeding)

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade III - Collecting System Involvement with Urinary Extravasation

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Laceration extending into collecting system; Urinary extravasation present
expectedOutputs.Kidney-Specific Note: Urinary extravasation resolves spontaneously in 80-90% of cases. Intervention indicated for enlarging urinoma, fever, persistent ileus, or suspected UPJ disruption.

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Laceration into collecting system with urinary extravasation = Grade III criterion. Step 4: Urinary extravasation confirmed. Step 5: Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade III: Laceration extending into collecting system with urinary extravasation (downgraded from Grade IV in earlier versions)

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade III - Partial Infarction

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Partial/segmental infarction

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: Partial/segmental infarction = Grade III criterion. Step 5: Final Grade = III.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale - Grade III: Partial or segmental kidney infarction

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade IV - Deep Calyceal Laceration

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Severe - Collecting system involvement or segmental vessel injury
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Deep laceration involving calyces; Urinary extravasation present; Hematoma rim distance >=3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Angioembolization for active bleeding; ureteral stent or nephrostomy for persistent urinoma; exploration for UPJ disruption

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: HRD >=3.5 cm = Grade III. Step 3: Deep laceration involving calyces = Grade IV criterion. Step 4: Urinary extravasation present but grade already IV. Step 5: Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale - Grade IV: Deep laceration involving calyces, renal pelvis, or UPJ

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade IV - UPJ Disruption

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Ureteropelvic junction disruption; Urinary extravasation present

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: UPJ disruption = Grade IV criterion. Step 4: Urinary extravasation present (expected with UPJ disruption). Step 5: Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018, Kidney Injury Scale - Grade IV: Complete or near-complete ureteropelvic junction disruption

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade IV - Segmental Vessel Injury

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Segmental infarction without active bleeding; Segmental artery/vein injury without active bleeding; Parenchymal laceration >=2.5 cm

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: Laceration >=2.5 cm = Grade III. Step 4: Segmental vessel injury without active bleeding = Grade IV. Step 5: Segmental infarction = Grade IV. Step 6: Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade IV: Segmental artery or vein injury without active bleeding

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade IV - Multifragmented Without Active Bleeding

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Multifragmented kidney without active bleeding; Pseudoaneurysm, AV fistula, or contained active bleeding; Urinary extravasation present; Hematoma rim distance >=3.5 cm

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: HRD >=3.5 cm = Grade III. Step 3: Shattered/multifragmented kidney without main vessel active bleeding = Grade IV. Step 4: Contained vascular injury = Grade III. Step 5: Final Grade = IV.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade IV: Multifragmented kidney without active bleeding

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade V - Main Renal Vessel Injury

expectedOutputs.Grade Description: Critical - Main vessel injury or shattered kidney with active bleeding
expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Main renal artery/vein laceration or transection with active bleeding; Deep laceration involving calyces; Urinary extravasation present; Hematoma rim distance >=3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Management Approach: High-risk injury; operative exploration often required; consider nephrectomy vs. reconstruction

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: HRD >=3.5 cm = Grade III. Step 3: Deep calyceal laceration = Grade IV. Step 4: Main renal artery/vein injury with active bleeding = Grade V criterion. Step 5: Final Grade = V (Critical).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V: Main renal artery or vein laceration or transection with active bleeding

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade V - Complete Infarction with Active Bleeding

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Complete kidney infarction with active bleeding; Active bleeding extending beyond Gerota fascia
expectedOutputs.Intervention Consideration: Nephrectomy for uncontrollable hemorrhage or complete devascularization; renal reconstruction if feasible

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: No hematoma. Step 3: No laceration. Step 4: Active bleeding beyond Gerota fascia = Grade IV. Step 5: Complete infarction with active bleeding = Grade V criterion. Step 6: Final Grade = V.
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V: Complete or near-complete kidney infarction with active bleeding

testCases.testName: Kidney Grade V - Shattered Kidney with Main Vessel Injury

expectedOutputs.Key Findings: Main renal artery/vein laceration or transection with active bleeding; Complete kidney infarction with active bleeding; Shattered kidney with active bleeding; Urinary extravasation present; Hematoma rim distance >=3.5 cm
expectedOutputs.Follow-up: Long-term renal function monitoring; blood pressure surveillance; contralateral kidney evaluation

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Identify organ (Kidney). Step 2: HRD >=3.5 cm = Grade III. Step 3: Shattered kidney with main vessel active bleeding = Grade V. Step 4: Main vessel injury = Grade V. Step 5: Complete infarction with active bleeding = Grade V. Step 6: Final Grade = V (Critical - multiple Grade V criteria met).
testCases.medicalReference: AAST-OIS 2018 - Grade V: Shattered kidney (multifragmented) with active bleeding from main renal vessels

key2018Updates.vascularInjuryIntegration: Pseudoaneurysm and arteriovenous fistula criteria added to imaging grading
key2018Updates.activeBleedingLocation: Contained vs. extending beyond organ now affects grade
key2018Updates.liverChanges: Couinaud hepatic segments removed from injury quantification
key2018Updates.spleenChanges: Trabecular vessel involvement removed; PSA/AVF added as Grade IV criteria
key2018Updates.kidneyChanges: Urinary extravasation downgraded to Grade III; hematoma rim distance (HRD) used for classification

multipleInjuryRule.description: Advance one grade for multiple injuries in same organ
multipleInjuryRule.applicability: Applies when base grade is I or II

managementPrinciples.gradeVsManagement: Anatomic grade alone does NOT dictate operative vs. non-operative management
managementPrinciples.highGrade: Grade III-V: May still be managed non-operatively if hemodynamically stable

wsesGuidelines.liver: WSES 2020 Liver Trauma Guidelines (Coccolini et al.)
wsesGuidelines.spleen: WSES Classification and Guidelines 2017 (Coccolini et al.)

primaryReferences.citation: Kozar RA, et al. Organ injury scaling 2018 update: Spleen, liver, and kidney. J Trauma Acute Care Surg. 2018;85(6):1119-1122.
Santo IDE, et al. Grading Abdominal Trauma: Changes in and Implications of the Revised 2018 AAST-OIS. RadioGraphics. 2023;43(9):e230040.
Moore EE, et al. Organ injury scaling: spleen, liver, and kidney. J Trauma. 1989;29(12):1664-1666.

gradeII.hematoma: Subcapsular 10-50% surface area OR intraparenchymal <10 cm

gradeIII.hematoma: Subcapsular >50% OR ruptured OR intraparenchymal >10 cm
gradeIII.vascular: Active bleeding contained within liver parenchyma

gradeIV.vascular: Active bleeding extending beyond liver into peritoneum

gradeV.vascular: Juxtahepatic venous injury (retrohepatic IVC/central hepatic veins)

gradeII.hematoma: Subcapsular 10-50% surface area OR intraparenchymal <5 cm

gradeIII.hematoma: Subcapsular >50% OR intraparenchymal >=5 cm OR ruptured

gradeIV.laceration: Segmental or hilar vessels with >25% devascularization
gradeIV.vascular: Pseudoaneurysm, AV fistula, OR contained active bleeding

gradeV.vascular: Active bleeding into peritoneum OR hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization

gradeI.hematoma: Subcapsular hematoma HRD <3.5 cm OR parenchymal contusion

gradeII.laceration: <2.5 cm parenchymal depth, no collecting system involvement

gradeIII.laceration: >=2.5 cm depth OR extending into collecting system with urinary extravasation
gradeIII.vascular: Pseudoaneurysm, AV fistula, or contained active bleeding

gradeIV.laceration: Deep laceration involving calyces, renal pelvis, or UPJ disruption OR multifragmented without active bleeding
gradeIV.vascular: Segmental artery/vein injury without active bleeding OR active bleeding beyond Gerota fascia

gradeV.vascular: Main renal artery or vein laceration/transection with active bleeding
gradeV.infarction: Complete kidney infarction with active bleeding
